awd_titl_txt: Development of Ga2O3 Based Structures for High Power Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description: In the past decade, wide-bandgap semiconductor materials such as GaN have enabled a variety of optoelectronic and electronic technologies by providing new capabilities at elevated temperatures and high voltages. This research project focuses on investigating the growth and fundamental properties of gallium oxide (Ga2O3), a material that has not been extensively explored for electronics. The knowledge gained in this study leads to high-quality gallium oxide materials with a low defect density and controllable electronic properties for high-power devices. The project topic increases public awareness of the importance of novel materials for energy-efficient power electronics, essential to our future quality of life. In addition, graduate and undergraduate students are trained in materials science research, with a special emphasis on involving underrepresented groups. The project also fosters interdisciplinary collaborations at local, national and international levels and transforms fundamental materials research findings to industry.

Technical Description: The scientific objective of this project is to establish the relationship between the thin-film growth and the structural and physical properties of Ga2O3. The Ga2O3 thin films are deposited using three complimentary growth techniques including pulsed laser deposition, pulsed electron deposition and metalorganic vapor phase deposition with the ultimate goal to explore its potential for power electronics. The research explores: (i) the optimum growth conditions of  beta-Ga2O3 through homoepitaxy and heteroepitaxy; (ii) interface strategies for defect reduction; (iii) doping options (e.g., Si, Sn and Mg) for high incorporation efficiency and enhanced conductivities; (iv) annealing procedures for improving the structural and electrical properties; and (v) in-plane anisotropy and its effects on electrical and thermal transport properties. The study provides a fundamental understanding of the roles of defects and dopants on the overall structural and electrical properties in this wide bandgap material.

por.por_cntn:
The outcome of the project concerning intellectual merit include better understanding of dielectric and conducting and thermal properties of β-Ga2O3 at room and elevated temperatures, relevant for high-power devices. The effects of dislocations, impurities and anisotropy were found significant and approaches for their accounting were developed and disseminated.

Systematic study of N-type doping of β-Ga2O3 homoepitaxial thin films grown by PLD by using Si and Sn dopants has been performed. Different targets with variable Si and Sn mole fractions (up to 10%), both commercial and homo-prepared were employed for the deposition of doped materials and the growth conditions were tuned in order to optimize the layer morphology and crystalline quality. Annealing conditions were also varied with the goal to enhance the donor activation and free carrier concentration. Hall effect and THz spectroscopy were performed at variable temperature to assess the electronic transport. 

We have studied the effect of Sn and Fe doping on thermal conductivity of β-Ga2O3 at elevated temperatures. A unique approach for extracting the thermal conductivity of the lateral and transverse heat flow directions was developed in order to solve the issue of the two-dimensional heat flow of the 3ω method in the crystal with anisotropic properties. Results for the thermal conductivity at room temperature clearly illustrated the highly anisotropic behavior of β-Ga2O3, with the difference between the directions of highest and lowest thermal conductivity being ~50%. The temperature dependence of the thermal conductivity was not found to significantly change with doping, which is a beneficial property for the design of devices.

Transient thermoreflectance (TTR) technique has also been employed to study the thermal conductivity of β-Ga2O3 semiconductors. The low thermal conductivity was attributed to the strong Umklapp phonon-phonon scattering in β-Ga2O3. It was also found that the phonon-boundary scattering is essential in thin β-Ga2O3 layers even at high temperatures and the thermal conductivity strongly deviated from the common 1/T temperature dependence. The results were also compared with another ultra-wide bandgap material AlGaN with high Al content and with results previously reported by the 3omega method.

Dielectric and conducting properties of undoped and Sn-doped β-Ga2O3 have been studied by time-domain terahertz spectroscopy. Complex permittivity and optical conductivity spectra from 0.25 to 2.5 THz were experimentally studied in a broad range of temperatures. Upon heating, the influence of this optical conductivity mechanism strongly increases, and the sample becomes opaque in the THz range near 100 K. The Sn-doped Ga2O3 thin film sample exhibited a much higher optical conductivity than the undoped bulk sample, and its spectra are remarkably stable over a broad temperature range (4-750 K).

Deep UV photodetectors using PLD grown β-Ga2O3 have been studied, employing pulsed laser deposition (PLD) grown oriented single crystalline β-gallium oxide (β-Ga2O3) thin films on c-plane sapphire substrates by optimized growth temperature and pressure. The morphology and crystallinity of the thin films are examined by X-ray diffraction and atomic force microscopy, confirming their high quality. All samples showed high transmittance of visible light (>90%) while providing a cutoff wavelength of 255nm. A 5 eV bandgap was found using the Tauc method. The thin films were used as the semiconductor layer for metal-semiconductor-metal (MSM) photodetector devices with various electrode designs. The ultraviolet photodetectors were characterized under 250 nm illumination, showing a high current amplitude increase over dark current conditions that approached three orders of magnitude at a 6 V bias for an optimized growth pressure of 1x10-3 Torr. The MSM photodetector transient response was measured, and the analysis provides insight into the relationship between relaxation time constants and thin film defect density.

Beta-Ga2O3 thin-channel metal-oxide-semiconductor field-effect transistors (MOSFETs) were evaluated using both DC and pulsed I-V measurements, as well as Raman nano-thermography. The pulsed I-V technique was used to study self-heating effects in the MOSFET channel. The device was analyzed over a large temperature range of 23 to 200C.  A relationship between dissipated power and channel temperature was established, and it was found that the MOSFET channel was heating up to 208?C when dissipating 2.5 W/mm of power. The thermal resistance of the channel was found to be 73?C-mm/W. The results were supported by experimental Raman nano-thermography and thermal simulations and were found in reasonable agreement with pulsed I-V findings. The high thermal resistance underpins the importance of optimizing thermal management in future Ga2O3 devices.

Broader impact of this project includes training graduate students in oxide materials synthesis and characterization, developing skills in preparing publications and presentations of results at conferences. The results from the project were broadly disseminated via journal and proceedings publications. The project findings contribute to wide bandgap materials science and semiconductor device engineering. Providing critically important data on fundamental material parameters and better understanding of the conducting, dielectric and thermal transport properties directly influences all the technology procedures optimizing the design of high-power electronic devices.
